pros: - Freedom to innovate - staff are easily able to implement new things without the regular lethargic bureaucracy of similar organizations. - Large reach - Because SFL works in Senegal Gambia & Bissau, you'll get a chance to work in in numerous environments - Amazing team of people - That famous Teranga hospitality is quite real. The people of Senegal, Gambia & Guinea-Bissau are a joy to work with inside and outside the organization
cons: - Lack of structures - Organizational structures are there for a reason. It really is the wild west in terms of organizational structure. Anything can happen in the organization based on the subjectiveness or emotion of 2 individuals. It's not that policies don't exist, they are simply used for blaming employees when things go wrong; or if they are required for audits; or as excuses for limiting expenses Extremely high staff turnover rate - From Chief of Party, Consultants, Managers, Officers & assistants, team members constantly left the organization in the period of time I was there. - Toxic Work Environment - Any bottom-up feedback was met with yelling at best and a poor performance review at worst. The roofs of the Senegal office would leak during the rainy season and everyone was always tense. - Poor executive management - SFL's executive management team leaves a lot to be desired. There's barely any gender and disability inclusivity. Extremely poor communication and unnecessary secrecy. Constant blame games; Blatant nepotism; Office gossip being factored into performance reviews. Unrealistic goals setting and task assignment. All these issues are as a result of systemic poor leadership & management. - Lack of alignment with mission - SFL does not care about it's mission. Everything is done for donor funding rather than the project's missions. If you are offered a position there. Accept job offer at your own risk
